document.docTitle: Cytochrome P450 enzymes: A driving force of plant diterpene diversity

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Cytochrome P450 enzymes: A driving force of plant diterpene diversity

subSection.paragraph: Review

paragraph.docTitle: Cytochrome P450 enzymes: A driving force of plant diterpene diversity

paragraph.emphasis: Department of Cell and Metabolic Biology, Leibniz Institute of Plant Biochemistry, Weinberg 3, 06120 Halle, Germany

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O
Plant diterpenoid biosynthesis Cytochrome P450 oxygenases Phylogeny
Evolution
A B S T R A C T

In plant terpene biosynthesis, oxidation of the hydrocarbon backbone produced by terpene synthases is typically carried out by cytochrome P450 oxygenases (CYPs). The modifications introduced by CYPs include hydroxylations, sequential oxidations at one position and ring rearrangements and closures. These reactions significantly expand the structural diversity of terpenoids, but also provide anchoring points for further decorations by various transferases. In recent years, there has been a significant increase in reports of CYPs involved in plant terpene pathways. Plant diterpenes represent an important class of metabolites that includes hormones and a number of industrially relevant compounds such as pharmaceutical, aroma or food ingredients. In this review, we provide a comprehensive survey on CYPs reported to be involved in plant diterpene biosynthesis to date. A phylogenetic analysis showed that only few CYP clans are represented in diterpene biosynthesis, namely CYP 71, CYP 85 and CYP 72. Remarkably few CYP families and subfamilies within those clans are involved, indicating specific expansion of these clades in plant diterpene biosynthesis. Nonetheless, the evolutionary trajectory of CYPs of specialized diterpene biosynthesis is diverse. Some are recently derived from gibberellin biosynthesis, while others have a more ancient history with recent expansions in specific plant families. Among diterpenoids, labdane-related diterpenoids represent a dominant class. The availability of CYPs from diverse plant species able to catalyze oxidations in specific regions of the labdane-related backbones provides opportunities for combinatorial biosynthesis to produce novel diterpene compounds that can be screened for biological activities of interest.

Terpenoids constitute a large group of natural products whose beneficial effects have already been appreciated by ancient Egyptians ( Larayetan et al., 2017 ; Maimone and Baran, 2007 ). It is estimated that over 55 000 terpenoid structures have been identified so far ( Christianson, 2008 ), which is probably only a fraction of what can be found in Nature, making it the largest class of natural products. Terpenoids are derived from the universal C- 5 building blocks, dimethylallyl diphosphate (DMAPP) and isopentenyl diphosphate (IPP). In plants two pathways contribute to the supply of DMAPP and IPP. The cytosolic mevalonate (MEV) pathway is common to all Eukaryotes and Archaebacteria, whereas the methylerythritol phosphate pathway (MEP) is present in the plastids of plants, in Bacteria and in some Protozoa ( Lichtenthaler, 1999 ). The sequential condensation of DMAPP with IPP catalyzed by isoprenyldiphosphate synthases leads to the formation of the starting molecules that define the different classes of terpenes. The most common isoprenyl diphosphates are geranyl (GPP, C- 10), farnesyl (FPP, C- 15) and geranylgeranyl ( GGPP , C- 20), although some cis -isoprenyl diphosphates have been found to be substrates of terpene synthases ( Sallaud et al., 2009 ; Schilmiller et al., 2009 ).

Terpenoid biosynthesis can be divided into three major steps, each contributing to the structural diversity of this compound class. Terpene synthases ( TPS ) constitute the first step and convert linear isoprenyl diphosphates to linear or cyclic terpene olefins or terpene alcohols. Collectively, TPS generate the diversity of the terpene backbone structures found in Nature. They can catalyze the formation of one major product or of several products in defined relative amounts. Some TPS can accept several isoprenyl diphosphates (e.g. GPP and FPP) while others are specific for one substrate ( Degenhardt et al., 2009 ). In the next step, terpenes, or terpene alcohols, are typically oxidized at specific positions and in a stereospecific manner. In plants, the vast majority of the terpene oxidations reported so far are carried out by cytochrome P450 oxygenases (CYPs), but some can be brought about by dioxygenases and various types of dehydrogenases. These oxidations can occur sequentially at a given position to give rise to carboxylic acids, but can also lead to rearrangements of the terpene backbone structure, for example by creating novel C-C linkages. Also, some enzymes are able in vitro or in other organisms to oxidize a given backbone at distinct positions or to oxidize related substrates. To what extent this apparent promiscuity is relevant in planta and whether this is a general property of enzymes of specialized metabolism is still unclear. In the final block of reactions, further functionalization of the oxidized terpenoids occurs by the addition of a variety of substituents, including acyl, glycosyl, benzoyl, or even alkaloid groups.

The structural diversity of the diterpene backbone is generated by the family of diterpene synthases (diTPS). Recent excellent reviews cover this topic ( Zerbe and Bohlmann, 2015b ) and we will only briefly present the major diterpene structural classes and their origins here. Diterpene synthases metabolize (E,E,E,E) - GGPP , except for a few cases where nerylneryl diphosphate is used ( Zi et al., 2014b ), to the 20- carbon backbones of all diterpenoids. Plant terpene synthases ( TPS ), and diTPS in particular, constitute a conserved protein family with characteristic amino acid motifs that are required for catalysis. Although non-seed plant lineages do contain TPS that show similarity to microbial TPS ( Jia et al., 2018 ), the TPS in seed plants belong to one phylogenetic group. The ancestral plant terpene synthase was most likely a diterpene synthase, as suggested by the fact that the single functional terpene synthase in the moss
Physcomitrella patens
is a bifunctional diterpene synthase, PpCPS/KS, that produces ent -kaurene, 16-hydroxy- ent -kaurane as well as ent -beyerene and ent -sandaracopimaradiene ( Hayashi et al., 2006 ; Zhan et al., 2015 ). PpCPS/KS has two catalytic activities that act in sequence to generate the diterpene products. The first is an ent -copalyl diphosphate synthase (CPS) that uses GGPP as substrate. CPS belongs to the class II of terpene synthases that initiate cyclization by protonation of a carbon-carbon double bond ( Cao et al., 2010 ). The second activity is a kaurene synthase (KS) that converts ent -copalyl diphosphate to ent -kaurene and 16-hydroxy- ent - kaurane. KS belongs to the class I terpene synthases that initiate cyclization by abstraction of the diphosphate group through a Mg 2+ -dependent reaction ( Cao et al., 2010 ). This presumably ancestral bifunctional diTPS went through different evolutionary paths to give rise to the plant diterpene diversity that we observe in extant plant species. In Gymnosperms and early vascular plants (lycophytes), the bifunctionality was retained but through gene duplication events and neo-functionalization gave rise to diversification of products. Thus in conifers for example, diterpene resin acids are derived from diterpenes such as abietadiene or pimaradiene that are synthesized by bifunctional diTPS. Notably the neo-functionalization affected both the class I and the class II activities. The class II activity in bifunctional diTPS of the conifers evolved to produce ( + )-copalyl diphosphate, a stereoisomer of ent -copalyl diphosphate ( Vogel et al., 1996 ), or even in some cases copal-8-ol diphosphate, the precursor of cis -abienol, where the resolution of the cyclization reaction is achieved by water addition at the C- 8 position instead of a proton elimination as for copalyl diphosphate. The neo-functionalization of the class I activity gave rise to novel activities in terms of both substrates, e.g. to use the novel products of class II diTPS activities, and products. Thus from ( + )-copalyl diphosphate a number of tricyclic diterpenes can be synthesized including abietadiene, levopimaradiene and isopimaradiene ( Keeling et al., 2008 ).

In an alternative evolutionary path, the ancestral bifunctional diTPS duplicated and gave rise to independent class I and class II terpene synthases. This is the case for the biosynthesis of ent -kaurene, the precursor of the gibberellin hormones in vascular plants, where CPS and KS are encoded by similar but distinct genes, pointing to the common origin of these two enzymes ( Hedden and Thomas, 2012 ; Keeling et al., 2010 ). CPS and KS of the gibberellin biosynthesis are conserved throughout the evolution of vascular plants and typically encoded by single copy genes but, as with bifunctional diTPS, gene duplication events followed by neo-functionalization also gave rise to novel diterpene products ( Gao et al., 2012 ). The separation of class I and class II activities thus provided a fertile ground for the diversification of diterpene products. Interestingly, this neo-functionalization of class I and class II appears to have occurred essentially in Angiosperms, where diterpene diversity is probably at its highest in plants ( Zerbe and Bohlmann, 2015b ). All the diterpene products that are produced by sequential class II and class I activities have in common a bicyclic core structure and have therefore been named “labdane-related” ( Peters, 2010 ). Monofunctional class I diterpene synthases also evolved independently in several plant lineages. For example the taxadiene synthase of yew trees (
Taxus sp.
) involved in the biosynthesis of the anticancer drug Taxol
ª
uses GGPP as a substrate and in one step carries out a complex multiple cyclization reaction ( Köksal et al., 2011 ; Wildung and Croteau, 1996 ). In contrast to taxadiene synthase, which retains the overall α/β/γ structure of ancestral bifunctional diTPS, a clade of angiosperm-specific diTPS lost both the β and γ domains. In the nomenclature of Bohlmann et al. (1998) augmented by Chen et al. (2011) , this includes the tps-a, tps-b and tps-g families. Tps-a diTPS enzymes reported so far cyclize GGPP to macrocyclic structures of the cembrane or casbane type ( Ennajdaoui et al., 2010 ; Kirby et al., 2010 ; Mau and West, 1994 ; Wang and Wagner, 2003 ). An overview of the major groups of diterpene structures is shown in Fig. 1.

heading.emphasis: 3. Overview of plant CYPs involved in diterpene metabolism

emphasis.heading: 3.1. The plant diterpene CYPs constitute a phylogenetically diverse group
but are confined to few CYP families

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Major terpene synthase (TPS) classes and families of terpene backbones considered in this review. Class I TPS initiate cyclization by Mg 2+ -dependent phosphate abstraction and class II TPS initiate cyclization by protonation of a C-C double bond. The Tps family nomenclature is based on Bohlmann et al. (1998) revised by Chen et al. (2011) . Not shown are the bifunctional CPS/KS of moss and the Tps-e/f enzyme from tomato that uses nerylneryl diphosphate.

subSection.paragraph:
In contrast, the CYP 71 clan, a clan that is unique to land plants and includes more than 50% of all plant CYPs ( Hamberger and Bak, 2013 ; Nelson and Werck-Reichhart, 2011 ), has been investigated to a much greater extent. The phylogenetic analysis of diterpenoid CYP 71 clan members reveals a split into hormonal pathway (kaurene oxidases, KOs), known from all plant families, and angiosperm specialized metabolism. The latter comprises Lamiaceae phenolic diterpene ( CYP 71BE, CYP 71D, CYP 76AH, CYP 76AK and CYP 76BK), rice phytoalexin ( CYP 71Z, CYP 76M, CYP 99 A , and CYP 701 A ), Euphorbiaceae diterpene ( CYP 71D and CYP 726 A ) and Solanaceae diterpene ( CYP 71BN and CYP 71D) biosynthesis. Within that clan, more than half of all known angiosperm CYPs involved in specialized diterpene metabolism belong to the CYP 76 family. The rest of the CYP 71 clan is provided by CYP 71 family members and a few genes from the CYP 99 family (see Fig. 1 ). Interestingly, evolution of CYP 71 and CYP 76 families took place before monocots and eudicots separated because family members can be found in rice (monocot) and Lamiaceae or Euphorbiaceae (both eudicots). In
Oryza sativa
(rice) however, duplication events gave rise to five kaurene oxidase-like (KOL) genes, of which only OsKO2 is active in gibberellin biosynthesis ( Sakamoto et al., 2004 ). Of the other OsKOL genes, only OsKOL4 was reported so far to contribute to specialized phytoalexin biosynthesis, thus providing a nice example of neo-functionalization from a duplicated gene ( Wang et al., 2012b ). This indicates that gibberellin biosynthesis genes can serve as a sequence pool from which specialized CYPs can evolve. But our phylogenetic analysis shows that KOs ( CYP 701 A ) are generally not the common ancestor of specialized metabolic CYP 71 clan members despite their long evolutionary history. Indeed, KOs have been found in ancient plant species (e.g.
P. patens
) ( Miyazaki et al., 2011 ), and therefore most likely evolved long before the separation between Angiosperms and Gymnosperms ( Fig. 2 ).

The limited number of CYP families found among the diterpene CYPs also reflects the occurrence of expansions in specific plant families or taxonomic groups. Thus, the CYP 725 A family is specific to
Taxus sp.
, CYP 720B to resinous conifers, and CYP 726 A to the Euphorbiaceae ( Fig. 2 ). CYP 76s involved in diterpene metabolism are found in both monocots and eudicots, but here sub-families underwent expansion in specific plant taxa, like the CYP 76AH and CYP 76AK from the Lamiaceae . The occurrence of a limited number of CYP families among diterpene CYPs could also be interpreted as a bias due to the still relatively small number of plant families that have been investigated so far with regards to diterpenoid metabolism. It will be interesting to see in the future if this concentration within a reduced set of CYP families is a general trend or if novel families will appear as our knowledge of diterpenoid metabolism in plants expands.

emphasis.heading: 3.2. Substrate specificity and promiscuity of plant CYPs in diterpenoid
metabolism

subSection.paragraph: The number of identified diterpenoids in reactions involving CYPs, exceeds the number of CYPs known to be involved in their synthesis. This can be due to substrate promiscuity or to the capacity to carry out oxidations at several positions on a given backbone, which is in effect a specific case of substrate promiscuity. CYP 725As are the least promiscuous diterpene CYPs, usually accepting only a single substrate. KOs, KAOs, CYP 76AKs, rice phytoalexin CYPs and Euphorbiaceae CYPs are somewhat more flexible, partly because they carry out multiple oxidations at a single C-position. This holds true, for example, for KOs which convert ent -kaurene to ent -kaurenoic acid with the alcohol and the aldehyde forms as intermediates ( Helliwell et al., 2001 ). The most promiscuous CYPs from diterpene metabolism in planta are CYP 720Bs and CYP 76AHs, which tolerate a whole spectrum of related but slightly different substrates. For the CYP 720B subfamily, this was considered to result in an evolutionary advantage for plant survival ( Geisler et al., 2016 ; Hamberger et al., 2011 ; Keeling and Bohlmann, 2006 ). Whether the promiscuity of CYP 76AH enzymes also confers a selective advantage remains to be shown.

Considering the positions on the diterpene backbone where the oxidation takes place, CYP 720Bs and CYP 76AKs, but also KOs and KAOs from gibberellin biosynthesis, appear to be highly selective since they oxidize their substrate at a single C-position ( Fig. 2 , Table 2 ). With the present knowledge, CYP 99As and CYP 71Zs are also highly selective regarding the oxidized C-position, but the small number of known genes from these subfamilies makes it difficult to reach firm conclusions. In contrast, CYP 76AHs, CYP 76Ms as well as CYP 726As and CYP 71Ds from Euphorbiaceae oxidize at several positions, sometimes in different combinations ( Fig. 2 ). Especially for labdane-related diterpenoids, the flexibility of CYP 76s is remarkable, because they perform oxidations on eleven different C-positions ( Table 2 ). CYP 725As, somehow, form an exception because this CYP subfamily oxidizes taxane-derivatives at many different positions, although each single member is specific to a certain C-position. The high substrate selectivity of each CYP allows the complex biosynthesis downstream to Taxol
ª
and related taxanes ( Croteau et al., 2006 ).

caption.paragraph: Table 1 List of CYP families involved in primary and specialized diterpene production with number of derived products. For a more detailed list see supplementary information (Table S2).

Specialized labdane-related diterpene biosynthesis is dominated by the CYP76 family, whose members are often promiscuous. Here we present the C-positions of labdane-related diterpenoids that are oxidized by the given CYP subfamily. The underlined subfamilies are specific to a certain Cposition whereas the CYP76AH and CYP76M subfamilies decorate the substrate (given above as simplified structure) at multiple positions.

subSection.paragraph: Supporting the hypothesis of high substrate and mechanistic specificity but low flexibility in essential metabolisms ( Bar-Even et al., 2011 ; Weng, 2014 ), KOs and KAOs from gibberellin biosynthesis selectively accept single substrates across plant species. However, investigations on the promiscuity of Arabidopsis thaliana KO (AtKO) and rice KO2 (OsKO2) gave additional insights into substrate selectivity in hormone metabolism ( Mafu et al., 2016 ). It was observed that KOs do exhibit some promiscuity, and this to a different extent for the Arabidopsis and the rice KOs. Thus, OsKO2 accepting three ent -CPP-derived substrates ( ent -kaurene, ent -isokaurene and ent -trachylobane) is much less promiscuous then AtKO reacting on six substrates derived from ent -CPP, six from syn -CPP and one from normal CPP. However, AtKO carried out mostly single hydroxylation on substrates other than ent -CPP, indicating that the applied substrates were not the preferred ones. Nonetheless, this shows that enzymes involved in the biosynthesis of conserved signaling molecules can exhibit a certain degree of flexibility with regards to substrate specificity. In the case of Arabidopsis, it is conceivable that the somewhat relaxed substrate specificity of KO came about because of the absence of other labdane-related diterpenoids. In contrast, in rice the presence of labdanoids related to gibberellins could have led to a selection of more selective KO to prevent interference between hormone and specialized metabolism.

Regarding the issue of substrate specificity and promiscuity, we note that not all enzymes have been characterized in detail, making it difficult to evaluate how widespread this phenomenon is. Also, in vitro assays or expression in heterologous hosts constitute the basis for labeling enzymes as specific or promiscuous. In their original context however, these enzymes may encounter only a limited number, or even a single, relevant substrates. Thus, enzyme “promiscuity” may not be relevant in planta , but of interest for metabolic engineering applications, for example to generate new-to-nature products.

To better understand the reaction mechanisms and substrate preferences, homology modelling of CYPs has come into focus. It provides theoretical knowledge to predict amino acids from the active center presumably involved in substrate binding and turnover. The selected amino acids can subsequently be mutated and the impact of the introduced mutations on substrate or product evaluated. Protein engineering was carried out by Ignea and colleagues who created a library of random mutations on selected amino acid residues in the active site of
Pinus taeda
abietadiene oxidase. The substrate preference was changed and the catalytic activity could be increased ( Ignea et al., 2015 ). In a recent study, the structures of 11-hydroxy ferruginol synthases ( CYP 76AH22-24) and ferruginol synthases ( CYP 76AH1) were modelled to identify amino acid residues that determine the capacity to further hydroxylate ferruginol. Three key amino acids were found to contribute to the substrate and product specificity of each enzyme. Reciprocal mutagenesis of these amino acids was sufficient to convert the ferruginol synthases activity into 11-hydroxy ferruginol synthases and vice versa ( Scheler et al., 2016 ). In the absence of any crystal structure of CYPs involved in plant diterpene biosynthesis so far, homology modelling and site-directed mutagenesis offer a suitable approach to determine the catalytic mechanism, but also to create novel enzyme activities using synthetic biology tools.

In summary, on a global scale no clear trend as to the position of oxidation or the type of diterpene backbone used as substrate can be distinguished from the phylogenetic tree in Fig. 2 . One clear trend is the existence of families and sub-families of CYPs, which expanded in specific plant families and are involved in the oxidation of a group of diterpene backbones. In the next sections we will go through these in more detail.

heading.emphasis: 4. The role of cytochrome P450 enzymes in plant specialized diterpenoid metabolism

emphasis.heading: 4.1. The CYP 76 family is a dominant catalyzer of labdane diterpene
diversification in Lamiaceae

subSubSection.paragraph:
The Lamiaceae include more than 7800 species (www.theplantlist. org) many of which are used as spices or as medicinal plants ( Kokkini et al., 2003 ). Prominent examples are
Rosmarinus officinalis
,
Salvia sp.
or
Coleus forskohlii
which contain compounds of industrial relevance such as carnosic acid, carnosol, sclareol and forskolin, respectively ( Follin-Arbelet et al., 2015 ; Ibarra et al., 2011 ; Johnson, 2011 ). As fragrances, drug components or food additives – metabolites from Lamiaceae species have been of great interest for decades. Labdane-related diterpenoids, which can be found in more than 20 genera ( Vestri Alvarenga et al., 2001 ), contribute significantly to the interest in this plant family. A survey of diterpenes present in Lamiaceae predicted 91 different backbones ( Vestri Alvarenga et al., 2001 ). Knowing that each of these skeletons can be further oxidized at several positions, in different combinations, and that additional modifications such as acylation and glycosylation are possible, it is likely that the number of diterpenoids in Lamiaceae alone is close to or even in excess of 1000. In this structural diversification, CYPs of the CYP 76 family, and to a lesser extent from the CYP 71 family, play a dominant role in the oxidation of diterpenes in the Lamiaceae ( Fig. 3A , Table 1 ). The last five years have seen the characterization of CYPs from rosemary, sage species and
C. forskohlii
that participate in the biosynthesis of phenolic diterpenes, related tanshinones and the manoyl oxide derived forskolin, respectively. Most of them belong to the two distinct but closely related subgroups, CYP 76AH and CYP 76AK ( Fig. 2 ). The former are rather involved in the oxidation of olefinic or alcohol diterpenes. For example, CYP 76AH1 is a ferruginol synthase from
Salvia miltiorrhiza
which has been co-expressed with the required diTPS and cytochrome P450 reductase (SmCPR) in the model organism
Saccharomyces cerevisiae
to reconstruct ferruginol biosynthesis ( Guo et al., 2013 ). This step was proposed to be the first committed step in tanshinone biosynthesis in danshen (
S. miltiorrhiza
).
CYP 76AH1
RNAi lines of hairy root cultures of
S. miltiorrhiza
exhibited accumulation of the precursor miltiradiene in parallel to a reduction of downstream tanshinones proving the role of ferruginol as starting point for further decorations in tanshinone biosynthesis ( Ma et al., 2015 , 2016). Recent studies provided more insights into tanshinone biosynthesis by the characterization of SmCYP76AH3, which oxidizes ferruginol to 11-hydroxy ferruginol. The authors also demonstrated the promiscuity of these CYPs, which can oxidize their substrates at C 7, C 11 and C 12, leading to a spectrum of products ( Guo et al., 2016 ). The final steps in tanshinone biosynthesis have not been clarified so far but presumably require other types of reactions, C-C cleavage and decarboxylation, which may or may not be catalyzed by CYPs. Alternatively, it is conceivable that different enzyme families such as 2-oxoglutarate-dependent dioxygenases (2-ODD) participate in the downstream pathway as it can be inferred from 2-ODD RNAi lines of hairy root cultures which displayed reduced tanshinone content ( Xu and Song, 2017 ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 3. CYP activity in diterpene biosynthesis from plants. The substrate positions that are oxidized by the given CYPs are highlighted in the simplified terpene backbone structures. A, CYP activity in Lamiaceae . CYP76AHs catalyze oxidations of blue and red highlighted positions. X corresponds to a C- atom in rosemary and sage diterpene biosynthesis, and to an O-atom in forskolin biosynthesis from
C. forskohlii
. B, diterpene CYPs from rice. Some CYPs catalyze oxidations at various positions depending on their substrate. C, Euphorbiaceae CYP activity. The oxidized positions are C5, C6 and C9 in different combinations. D, Gibberellin and steviol biosyntheses involve activity of CYP714s. E, Diterpene resin acid biosynthesis in conifers include activity of CYP720Bs which oxidize exclusively at position C18. F, CYP725As activity in
Taxus sp.
The CYP, oxidizing C9, has not been found so far from
Taxus sp.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Species closely related to
S. miltiorrhiza
such as
Salvia fruticosa
,
Salvia pomifera
and
R. officinalis
also produce phenolic diterpenes. There, RoCYP76AH4, RoCYP76AH22-23 and Sf/SpCYP76AH24 are highly similar to SmCYP76AH1, but carry out two successive oxidations on the substrate miltiradiene/abietatriene at two different positions on the C-ring, leading to the synthesis of 11-hydroxy ferruginol (Bo ž i
ć et al., 2015
; Ignea et al., 2016 ; Scheler et al., 2016 ; Zi and Peters, 2013 ). Interestingly, these 11-hydroxy ferruginol synthases accept not only miltiradiene/abietatriene as substrate but also manoyl oxide, pointing to a certain degree of promiscuity of these enzymes not only with regards to the position but also to the diterpene substrate ( Pateraki et al., 2017 ).

Downstream of the hydroxy ferruginol synthases ( CYP 76AHs), four enzymes from
Salvia sp.
and
R. officinalis
of the CYP 76AK subfamily have been identified. They were collectively named C 20 oxidases because they oxidize their substrates at position C 20 ( Guo et al., 2016 ; Ignea et al., 2016 ; Scheler et al., 2016 ). Like CYP 76AHs, CYP 76AKs are promiscuous and therefore form a variety of metabolites. For example, Sf/SpCYP76AK6 and RoCYP76AK7-8 are involved in the biosynthesis of carnosic acid in
R. officinalis
,
S. fruticosa
and
S. pomifera
and catalyze three successive oxidations at C 20 on 11-hydroxy ferruginol to carnosic acid via the alcohol and the aldehyde (carnosaldehyde) as intermediates. Although, C 20 oxidases also have activity on ferruginol, yielding pisiferol, pisiferal and pisiferic acid, we showed that CYP 76AK8 favors 11-hydroxy ferruginol instead of ferruginol ( Scheler et al., 2016 ).

Next to C 20 oxidases from the carnosic acid pathway, there is one characterized C 20 oxidase from
S. miltiorrhiza , SmCYP
76AK1. It shares high sequence similarity with CYP 76AK6-8 (more than 68% on protein level) and is a promiscuous CYP that accepts several substrates and is proposed to be involved in tanshinone biosynthesis. SmCYP76AK1 introduces a single hydroxyl group at position C 20, unlike the C 20 oxidase involved in the biosynthesis of carnosic acid. This results in the production of 11,20-dihydroxy sugiol and 11,20-dihydroxy ferruginol, the latter spontaneously oxidizing to 10-hydroxymethyltetrahydromiltirone ( Guo et al., 2016 ). Spontaneous oxidation has also been shown for other phenolic diterpenes such as carnosic acid to carnosol and 11-hydroxy ferruginol to the corresponding quinone, which is a manifestation of the high antioxidant activities of these compounds ( Loussouarn et al., 2017 ; Scheler et al., 2016 ). It is still not clear whether the in planta conversion of carnosic acid to carnosol occurs via spontaneous oxidation or enzymatically.

Forskolin is a diterpene from
C. forskohlii
which has been long known for its positive effect on glaucoma, as inotrope and because of its vasodilatory activities ( Bristow et al., 1984 ; Caprioli et al., 1984 ; Wysham et al., 1986 ). Its biosynthesis has recently been clarified by Pateraki and co-workers including the characterization of involved CYPs and an acetyl transferase. Interestingly, as in the biosynthesis of carnosic acid, CYPs from the CYP 76AH subfamily, namely CfCYP76AH11 and CfCYP76AH15-16, are involved and catalyze five successive oxidations on manoyl oxide. CfCYP76AH15 was found to have activity on miltiradiene to form ferruginol , while CYP 76AH4 and CYP 76AH22-24 from rosemary and sage accepted manoyl oxide as substrate, providing nice examples of the promiscuity of this enzyme family ( Pateraki et al., 2017 ).

CYPs from the CYP 71 family were until now more known for their activities in mono- and sesquiterpene biosynthesis ( Mau and Croteau, 2006 ). In labdane-related diterpene biosynthesis, only two CYP 71s were found to be involved. CYP 71BE52 from
S. pomifera
and CYP 71D381 from
C. forskohlii
have hydroxylation activity on position C 2 of ferruginol and manoyl oxide, respectively ( Ignea et al., 2016 ). In addition, CfCYP71D381 hydroxylates at position C 19 ( Ignea et al., 2016 ; Pateraki et al., 2017 ). Interestingly, these CYPs share only 49% amino acid sequence similarity but can be collectively considered as C 2 oxidases.

Most recently, CYP 76BK1 from
Vitex agnus-castus
has been reported to oxidize peregrinol, a bicyclic diterpene, at position C 16 to labd-13Z- ene-9,15,16-triol. This compound is presumed to be an intermediate en route to furan- and lactone-containing diterpenoids ( Heskes et al., 2018 ). This constitutes yet another addition of a diterpene CYP to the CYP 76 family from Lamiaceae , further supporting the important role of this CYP family in diterpene diversification in Lamiaceae .

In Arabidopsis CYP 76 enzymes have been shown to be involved in the oxidation of monoterpenes ( Boachon et al., 2015 ; Hofer et al., 2014 ). Also, CYP 76 enzymes exist in Gymnosperms ( Nelson and Werck-Reichhart, 2011 ), and it remains to be seen whether in these species as well they are involved in the biosynthesis of similar compounds, such as pisiferic acid, a ferruginol derived carboxylic acid, from
Chamaecyparis pisifera ( Kobayashi et al., 1987 )
.

emphasis.heading: 4.2. Diterpene phytoalexin metabolism in rice is catalyzed by diverse CYP
families that are organized in two distinct biosynthetic gene clusters

subSection.paragraph:
The existence of metabolic gene clusters has now been confirmed in several plant species ( Nützmann and Osbourn, 2014 ; Nutzmann et al., 2016 ). The biosynthesis of rice diterpene phytoalexins provides a nice example because it is encoded by two metabolic gene clusters ( Nützmann and Osbourn, 2014 ; Prisic et al., 2004 ). On the one hand, OsCPS2 , OsKSL5-7 which code for kaurene synthase-like enzymes,
OsCYP 71Z6, OsCYP71Z7
and OsCYP76M5-8 form a multifunctional metabolic gene cluster for phytocassane and oryzalide biosynthesis on chromosome 2. On the other hand, the momilactone cluster comprises OsCPS4 , OsKSL4 ,
OsCYP99 A 2-3
and a short chain alcohol dehydrogenase called OsMAS ( Shimura et al., 2007 ; Swaminathan et al., 2009 ; Wilderman et al., 2004 ). Co-induction of momilactone cluster genes upon elicitation with UV irradiation or chitin oligosaccharide from fungal cell walls is in agreement with their involvement in the same pathway ( Itoh et al., 2004 ).

The activity of class I rice diTPS KSL4, KSL5, KSL6, KSL7, KSL8 and KSL10 supplies syn -pimara-7,15-diene, ent -kaur-15-ene, ent -pimara-8 (14),15-diene, ent -cassa-12,15-diene, syn -stemar-13-ene and ent -sandaracopimaradiene, respectively ( Peters, 2006 ; Schmelz et al., 2014 ). These labdanoid diterpenes are then potential substrates for oxidation by CYPs. While no CYPs are known yet for the biosynthesis of maize (
Zea mays
) kauralexins, diverse CYP families contribute to rice phytoalexin synthesis ( Fig. 3B ). Rice momilactone biosynthesis was proposed to proceed via syn -pimara-7,15-diene. It serves as substrate for OsCYP99 A 3, less so for OsCYP99 A 2, to
form syn
-pimaradien-19-oic acid in a three-step oxidation process. Although OsCYP99 A 3 also has activity on syn -stemodene to
form syn
-stemoden-19-oic acid, syn -pimara-7,15-diene is the favored substrate ( Wang et al., 2011 ). The downstream biosynthesis to momilactones is only partially elucidated. It was proposed that this pathway goes along 3β- hydroxy-9βH-pimaradiene-19,6β- olide which is converted to momilactone A by OsMAS, a short-chain alcohol dehydrogenase/reductase (SDR), and finally oxidized to momilactone B ( Atawong et al., 2002 ; Otomo et al., 2004 ; Wang et al., 2011 ).

Oryzalides A-C are antibacterial phytoalexins that derive from ent - kaur-15-ene. The entire pathway has not yet been clarified, but OsCYP71Z6 is a C 2 hydroxylase that acts on ent -kaur-15-ene en route to oryzalide A . The highly similar OsCYP71Z7 is a C 2 oxidase too, but reacts with ent -cassa-12,15-diene rather inefficiently. Therefore, it was assumed that the preferred substrate of OsCYP71Z7 is a different one, most likely downstream to phytocassanes A-E ( Wu et al., 2011 ). Next to OsCYP71Z7, OsCYP76M7-8 (catalyzing hydroxylation at position C 12) and OsCYP701 A 8 (promoting oxidation at C 3α) are assumed to be involved in the biosynthesis of antifungal phytocassanes. Notably, OsCYP 701 A 8 (also known as OsKOL4) belongs to the family of kaurene oxidase-like enzymes, indicating a recent evolution from KO (see above) ( Fig. 2 ). OsCYP701 A 8 (=OsKOL4) also accepts ent -kaurene and ent -sandaracopimaradiene to produce 3α- hydroxy- ent -kaurene and 3α- hydroxy- ent -sandaracopimaradiene, respectively ( Wang et al., 2012b ; Wu et al., 2013 ). It is not yet clear to what extent the remaining three OsKOLs ( CYP 701 A ) enzymes are involved in specialized diterpene metabolism in rice. For example, no activity on diterpene skeletons could be found for OsKOL5, but it is induced upon fungal infection ( Itoh et al., 2004 ).

3α- hydroxy- ent -sandaracopimaradiene is an intermediate in the biosynthesis of anti-microbial oryzalexins A-F. OsCYP76M6 and OsCYP76M8, from the same genetic cluster as OsCYP71Z6-7, catalyze downstream-oxidation of 3α- hydroxy- ent -sandaracopimaradiene to oryzalexin E and oryzalexin D, respectively ( Wu et al., 2013 ). The final biosynthetic steps to oryzalexins A-C are catalyzed by SDRs ( Kitaoka et al., 2016 ) while phytocassane synthesis remains poorly understood. But the promiscuity of OsCYP76M6 and OsCYP76M8 as well as of OsCYP 71Z7, OsCYP76M5 and OsCYP76M7 suggests they might be involved in downstream steps ( Wang et al., 2012a ).

emphasis.heading: 4.3. Gene clusters for diterpene metabolism in Euphorbiaceae are conserved
in several species

subSubSection.paragraph:
The Euphorbiaceae family contains 228 plant genera and around 6500 species (www.theplantlist.org). Some family members are used in traditional medicine in Arabia, China , India and in particular in Africa. They are used to treat inter alia epilepsy, anemia, diarrhea, cancer, fungal infections and oedema ( Chhabra et al., 1990 ). In many cases, bioactivity could be assigned to diterpenoids from these plants ( Beutler et al., 1989 ). They typically have a macrocyclic structure derived from the casbene, rosane, lathyrane, tigliane or ingenane backbones ( Vasas and Hohmann, 2014 ). In addition to ethnomedical knowledge, experimental data demonstrated the significance of Euphorbiaceae diterpenoids for therapeutic applications, including against cancer, HIV latent infection or to treat intractable pain (
Corea et al., 2009
; King et al., 2014 ; Lebwohl et al., 2012 ; Reis et al., 2013 ). The genes currently known to be involved in Euphorbiaceae diterpene biosynthesis share a high degree of conservation and organization, typically in genetic clusters. For example,
Ricinus communis
(castor bean) has a biosynthetic cluster with several genes coding for two casbene synthases (CBSs), one neocembrene synthase, six CYP726As (CYP726A13-18), two SDRs, one BAHD acyltransferase, two CYPs from the CYP80C family and one TPSg terpene synthase likely involved in monoterpene biosynthesis. Similar biosynthetic clusters can be found in
Euphorbia peplus
, revealing genes encoding a CBS and CYP726A19, and on chromosome 1 of
Jatropha curcas
with three CBSs, five CYP726As (CYP726A20, CYP726A21, CYP726A23, CYP726A24 and CYP726A35), two CYPs from the CYP71D subfamily, four alkenal reductases and three monoterpene synthases ( Boutanaev et al., 2015 ; King et al., 2014 , 2016). Remarkably, these genetic clusters occur in species that belong to distinct major sub-families. It was therefore concluded that the production of Euphorbiaceae diterpenoids evolved early in the emergence of this plant family more than 100 million years ago ( King et al., 2014 ). During evolution upstream biosynthetic enzymes providing the diterpene backbones (for example casbene, jatrophane or pepluane) kept a high degree of conservation across species because the different backbone types were found in several species ( Shi et al., 2008 ).

In the pathway of casbene-derived diterpenoids, CYP71 clan subfamily members of CYP726A and CYP71D appear to be the driving force for the production of higher oxidized derivatives ( Fig. 3C ). Some of them are promiscuous and accept not only casbene but also neocembrene. While CYP726A15 from
R. communis
oxidizes neocembrene at C5, casbene can be oxidized at C5, C6 and C9 by CYP726A14 and CYP726A17-18 from
R. communis
, by CYP726A20, CYP726A35 and CYP71D495 from
J. curcas
, by CYP726A27 and CYP71D445 from
Euphorbia lathyris
, and by CYP726A19, CYP71D365 and CYP726A4 from
E. peplus
( Boutanaev et al., 2015 ; King et al., 2014 ; Luo et al., 2016 ). Due to the large number of existing casbene-5-oxidases, this catalytic activity was concluded to be a key step in the biosynthesis of Euphorbiaceae diterpenoids and provides further evidence of a conserved biosynthetic pathway within this plant family ( King et al., 2014 ). Downstream, an alcohol dehydrogenase from
E. lathyris , ADH
1, was recently found to convert 6-keto-5,9-casbenediol into jolkinol C, although the same reaction on the highly similar 6-hydroxy-5,9-diketocasbene can occur spontaneously ( King et al., 2016 ; Luo et al., 2016 ). The formation of jolkinol C is characterized by a ring-closure, which is also indispensable for jatrophane, ingenane, myrsinane, daphnane, and lathyrane diterpenes. One can therefore assume that it represents a key step in Euphorbiaceae diterpenoid biosynthesis. However, biosynthetic genes of other Euphorbiaceae diterpenes remain unknown, and further research is necessary to elucidate the pathway of more complex Euphorbiaceae metabolites such as resiniferatoxin, ingenol mebutate and prostratin.

emphasis.heading: 4.4. CYP 714s: a crossover between gibberellin and steviol glycoside
biosynthesis

subSection.paragraph:
GAs are plant diterpene hormones that have essential functions in plant growth and development and are conserved in vascular plants dating their appearance to around 400 MYA ( Zi et al., 2014a ). Nonvascular plants such as the moss
P. patens
can only produce ent -kaurenoic acid ( Miyazaki et al., 2011 ). CYPs are involved in the early steps of GA biosynthesis and provide ent -kaurenoic acid and subsequently GA 12 , a substrate for 2-ODD activity en route to bioactive GAs ( Hedden and Thomas, 2012 ). As seen above in the case of the rice phytoalexins, not only did genes from specialized diterpenoid metabolism evolve from those involved in GA biosynthesis, but also some diterpenes share intermediates with those of the GA pathway. This is the case for example for steviol glycosides which branch off of ent -kaurenoic acid ( Fig. 3D ). Steviol glycosides constitute a group of compounds from
Stevia rebaudiana
that can taste as much as 300 times sweeter than sucrose and are therefore of high commercial interest ( Goyal et al., 2010 ). C 13-hydroxylation by
A . thaliana
CYP 714 A results in steviol en route to steviol glycoside biosynthesis, but no homologue has been identified from
S. rebaudiana
( Brandle and Telmer, 2007 ; Nomura et al., 2013 ). CYP 714s are otherwise known as inactivating GA in planta and thereby contribute to controlling growth processes ( Magome et al., 2013 ; Nomura et al., 2013 ; Zhang et al., 2011 ).

emphasis.heading: 4.5. CYP 720B is a conifer-specific CYP subfamily involved in defense
reactions

subSection.paragraph:
Diterpene resin acids (DRAs) together with mono- and sesquiterpenes constitute a highly efficient mixture, also known as oleoresin, to counter pests in conifers. Upon herbivory and pathogenic attack the oleoresin is secreted at the entry point to exert chemical defense mechanisms or to form a physical barrier. In addition to toxicity, DRAs can harden upon contact with air, thereby effectively sealing the wound ( Keeling and Bohlmann, 2006 ). The compounds are also released upon mechanical wounding or treatment with methyl jasmonate, which mimic herbivory and associated defense signaling strategies ( Martin et al., 2002 ; Miller et al., 2005 ; Schmidt et al., 2011 ). The involved genes, namely diTPS and CYPs, are upregulated upon those treatments ( Byun-McKay et al., 2006 ; Funk et al., 1994 ; Hamberger et al., 2011 ; Ralph et al., 2006 ). In this section we focus on CYPs involved in the formation of tricyclic DRAs because no CYPs from bicyclic DRA biosynthesis are known to date. The dominant catalyzers in the biosynthesis of tricyclic DRAs are CYP 720Bs from the CYP 85 clan that are unique to resinous conifers ( Fig. 3E ). They accept various olefinic precursors (abietadiene and abietadiene-like, pimaradiene and pimaradiene-like, palustrastradiene and dehydrabietadiene/abietatriene) or 13-hydroxy-8 (14)-abietene as substrates. The first identified family member was CYP 720B1 from
Pinus taeda
for which orthologues were later detected in the genomes of
Pinus contorta
,
Pinus banksiana
and
Pinus brutia
( Geisler et al., 2016 ; Ro et al., 2005 ; Semiz and Sen, 2015 ). Ro and colleagues identified its activity as a C 18 oxidase and could prove the promiscuity of the enzyme by performing assays with the substrates abietadiene (rather inefficient conversion), abietadienol, abietadienal, levopimaradienol, isopimara-7,15-dienol, isopimara-7,15- dienal, dehydroabietadienol and dehydroabietadienal. The closely related CYP 720B4 from
Picea sitchensis
is a C 18 oxidase too, but is much more promiscuous than CYP 720B1. Remarkably, it is able to oxidize in total 24 substrates to the corresponding C 18-acids ( Hamberger et al., 2011 ). For example, PsCYP720B4 was recently reported to produce miltiradienic acid when co-expressed with TPS 9 and TPS 27 from
Tripterygium wilfordii ( Forman et al., 2017 )
.

The authors grouped these CYP 720Bs in four clades (I to IV) based on functional and phylogenetic criteria. While CYP 720B1 and CYP 720B4 are classified as clade III CYPs because they oxidize diterpene olefins, CYP 720B2 and CYP 720B12 from clade I use 13-hydroxy-8 (14)-abietene as substrate, an unstable product of levopimaradiene/abietadiene synthase. Regardless of the substrate, the final products are the C 18-acids (abietic acid, neoabietic acid, levopimaric acid and palustric acid) by non-enzymatic elimination of water ( Geisler et al., 2016 ). The substrate variability of clade I and III CYPs is presumably part of an ecological strategy to ensure effective defense mechanisms in conifers against herbivory and pathogens ( Fig. 4 ). It is, however, not clear if clade II and IV CYPs contribute to DRA biosynthesis or if they are involved in other biosynthesis pathways.

heading.emphasis: 4.6. Plant taxane biosynthesis is a complex pathway dominated by

subSection.paragraph:
Paclitaxel, also known as Taxol
ª
, is a diterpenoid compound from yew species that possesses powerful anti-cancer activity ( Weaver, 2014 ). Its natural occurrence is limited to a maximum of 500 μg per gram dried yew needles and therefore reliable supply has proved challenging ( van Rozendaal et al., 2000 ). At present, paclitaxel is produced either semi-synthetically from Baccatin III or other taxane derivatives which can be isolated in suitable amounts from yew needles ( Baloglu and Kingston, 1999 ; Chau et al., 2004a ) or from
Taxus
cell suspension cultures ( Zhong, 2002 ). Total synthesis has also been documented ( Nicolaou et al., 1994 ), but it is too expensive and therefore recombinant synthesis in microorganisms constitutes a conceivable alternative, but depends on the detailed knowledge and availability of the pathway genes ( Kaspera and Croteau, 2006 ; Patel, 1998 ). The biosynthesis of paclitaxel is eminently complex and requires in total 19 enzymatic steps from which eight are CYP-mediated and the others involve acetylation and side-chain assembly reactions ( Chau et al., 2004a ). The hydrocarbon backbone taxa-4 (5), 11 (12)-diene is provided by taxadiene synthase from GGPP and subsequently undergoes several oxidations ( Köksal et al., 2011 ). Kaspera and Croteau (2006) suggested the order of biosynthetic reactions with oxidations first at C 5 followed by C 10, C 13, C 9, C 7 and C 2 oxygenation (see Fig. 3F ). The product of C 2 oxidation then gets epoxidized and finally oxidized at position C 1 ( Kaspera and Croteau, 2006 ). Taxoid 5α-, 10β-, 13α-, 7β- and 2α- hydroxylases (TcuCYP725 A 4, TcuCYP725 A 1, TcuCYP725 A 2, TcuCYP725 A 5 and TcaCYP725 A 6, respectively), which carry out some of the mentioned reactions, were classified as CYP 725 A family members ( Chau and Croteau, 2004 ; Chau et al., 2004a ; Jennewein et al., 2001 , 2004; Schoendorf et al., 2001 ). Taxoid 14β- hydroxylase (TcuCYP725 A 3) decorating 5α- acetyl taxoids was suggested to play a key role in the early diversion of taxoid biosynthetic pathway and does not contribute to paclitaxel biosynthesis ( Jennewein et al., 2003 ; Kaspera and Croteau, 2006 ). CYP 725As from taxoid biosynthesis underwent gene expansion ( Fig. 2 ) including the evolution of divergent product specificities, but share around 70% sequence identity.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. The impact of selection pressure on CYP-derived diterpenoid diversity in plants. Genetic adaptation of plants to the surrounding challenges led to a high diversity of diterpene structures produced by CYPs. The chemical flexibility increases plant fitness and potential for adaptation to a changing environment. The CYP3D-model is from Scheler et al. (2016) .

subSection.paragraph:
Taxoid 5α- hydroxylase (TcuCYP725 A 4) was shown to oxidize taxa- 4 (5), 11 (12)-diene and taxa-4 (20), 11 (12)-diene, but yielded only one product, namely taxa-4 (20), 11 (12)-dien-5α- ol ( Edgar et al., 2016 ; Jennewein et al., 2004 ). It serves as substrate for an O-acetyltransferase and subsequently for taxoid 10β- hydroxylase to yield taxadien-5α- acetoxy-10β- ol; or for taxoid 13α- hydroxylase which gives taxadien- 5α,13α- diol. However, the catalytic activity of TcuCYP725 A 4 was reevaluated and shown to result, in addition to taxadien-5α- ol, in the formation of 5 (12)-oxa-3 (11)-cyclotaxane via a complex rearrangement involving the formation of a C-C bond and an internal ether linkage ( Rontein et al., 2008 ), results that were confirmed subsequently when TcuCYP725 A 4 was expressed in
Escherichia coli ( Ajikumar et al., 2010 )
. Taxoid 10β- hydroxylase and taxoid 13α- hydroxylase are promiscuous, converting not only their preferred substrate but also accept each other's ( Chau et al., 2004b ; Jennewein et al., 2001 ; Schoendorf et al., 2001 ). Downstream, oxidative decoration at C 9 is necessary, but so far no suitable CYP has been identified. Croteau and co-workers reported on a candidate but no structure elucidation could be performed due to low amounts of the yielded product ( Croteau et al., 2006 ). Interestingly, a taxoid 9α- hydroxylase of the CYP 716B subfamily from
Ginkgo biloba
cells was shown to convert the taxane derivative sinenxan A to 9α- OH sinenxan A ( Zhang et al., 2014 ). Our phylogenetic analysis shows that GbCYP716B co-clusters with the CYP 725s, and could represent an ancestral branch of the CYP 725 family ( Fig. 2 ) ( Nelson and Werck-Reichhart, 2011 ).

The exact function of taxoid 7β- hydroxylase and taxoid 2α- hydroxylase in the Taxol
ª
pathway has not been precisely characterized, but they oxidize the taxane derivative taxusin at positions C 7 and C 2, respectively ( Chau and Croteau, 2004 ; Chau et al., 2004a ). Interestingly, products of upstream hydroxylases were not metabolized and acetylations of intermediates increased substrate binding ( Chau et al., 2004a ). This strongly suggests that high substrate specificity of taxoid 7β- hydroxylase and taxoid 2α- hydroxylase regarding the acetylated intermediates enables the formation of complex taxanes without additional by-products. En route to paclitaxel, no candidate genes for oxidations at positions C 1, or for the side chain appending or epoxidation at C 4/ C 20 could be characterized so far, although several members of the CYP 725 A subfamily have been identified by RNAseq recently and are thus potential candidates ( Liao et al., 2017 ).

heading.emphasis: 4.7. Isolated examples of diterpenoids found in Solanaceae species

subSubSection.paragraph:
In the Solanaceae , only two examples of CYPs acting on diterpenes have been reported so far. Unlike in Lamiaceae , these are not labdane-related diterpenes. In
Nicotiana tabacum
, the trichome-specific CYP71D16 converts the macrocyclic diterpene alcohols α- and β- cembratrien-ol to α- and β- cembratrien-diol, respectively. Silencing of
CYP71D 16
in
N. tabacum
results in accumulation of α- and β- cembratrien-ol and increases resistance against aphids ( Wang et al., 2001 ). NtCYP71D16 is related to CYP71s that are involved in the oxidation of the tobacco sesquiterpene phytoalexin capsidiol ( Ralston et al., 2001 ). It is therefore possible that NtCYP71D16 evolved from this branch of the CYP71 family that was initially involved in the oxidation of sesquiterpenes.

subSection.paragraph: Some conclusions can be drawn from our analysis. The first is that CYPs involved in plant specialized diterpene biosynthesis belong to a limited set of clans, namely CYP 71 and CYP 72 in Angiosperms and CYP 85 in Gymnosperms. However, beyond these large clans there is no general rule for the assignment of the catalytic function of CYPs in diterpene biosynthesis. This is not surprising, given that plant diterpenoids are specialized metabolites for which structural sub-classes are restricted to certain plant families or even in some cases plant genuses (e.g. taxanes) ( Fig. 2 ). However, some families are associated with specific taxonomic groups (e.g. CYP 76s in Lamiaceae and rice, CYP 725As in Taxus and CYP 726As in Euphorbiaceae ) where they contribute to the metabolic diversity of specific subgroups of diterpenoids. In addition to this clade-specific expansion of sub-families of CYPs, specialized diterpene CYPs were found to derive via gene duplication from hormonal CYPs such as KOs and CYP 714s. In the case of CYP 76, the presence of members involved in specialized diterpene metabolism in rice and Lamiaceae suggests an origin predating the monocot and eudicot separation.

One should note that CYP families covered in this review are not always exclusively involved in diterpene biosynthesis. For example a CYP 88 related to kaurenoic acid oxidases was found to be involved in triterpenoid biosynthesis in licorice ( Seki et al., 2008 ). We also mentioned earlier CYP 76s from Arabidopsis playing a role in monoterpene oxidation and CYP 71s that are involved in the oxidation of sesqui- or monoterpenes. Interestingly however, these cross-over cases are involved in terpene biosynthesis in general. It would therefore be interesting to extend this study on CYPs to terpenoids in general.

One clear trend from our analysis is that CYPs able to oxidize a class of diterpene in one plant family or species often belong to a sub-family which has expanded within a taxonomic clade. Thus, the CYP 76AH and CYP 76AK families constitute prime candidates when mining for diterpenoid CYPs in Lamiaceae which have not been explored yet. Given the substrate promiscuity already observed for some members of these sub-families, one can speculate that additional CYP 76 members from the Lamiaceae are likely to carry out additional reactions on labdane-related backbones at C-positions for which no catalyst is available yet. Identification of novel candidate genes can be based on co-expression analysis and the presence of genomic clusters. However, provided higher-throughput methods for cloning and expression are available, members of specific CYP sub-families can be systematically screened for novel activities. Such methods have been developed in yeast, using conventional or Golden Gate cloning tools combined with yeast expression and have proven highly efficient at exploring the diversity of labdane-related biosynthesis or for the elucidation of the carnosic acid pathway and reconstituting it in yeast ( Ignea et al., 2015 , 2016 ; Scheler et al., 2016 ). This approach is well adapted to a high-throughput testing of CYPs on a given diterpene backbone. Recently, combinations of class II and class I diTPS resulted in the production of over 50 products, 41 of which were considered as novel (or “new to nature”) ( Andersen-Ranberg et al., 2016 ). Combinatorial biosynthesis of diterpenes has also been successfully established in bacterial systems, providing an alternative production platform to yeast ( Jia et al., 2016 ; Mafu et al., 2016 ). Thus, combining libraries of diterpene synthases and of pre-selected CYP families has the potential to result in the rapid production of hundreds of novel diterpenoids, which can then be screened for biological activities of interest. When compounds with potential activity have been identified, their production can be further optimized to meet industrial standards. In that regard, the development of yeast strains producing the artemisinin precursor artemisinic acid with titers of 25 g / L culture ( Paddon et al., 2013 ) serves as a model for the engineering of other terpenoids and other natural products in yeast.

subSection.paragraph: Ulschan Bathe studied Biochemistry at the Martin-Luther University, Halle-Wittenberg, Germany , and obtained a Masters degree in 2013 with her work on the carnosic acid pathway in rosemary. Since 2014 she is a PhD student at the Leibniz-Institute of Plant Biochemistry in Halle, Germany , where she investigates the biosynthesis of phenolic diterpenes in Lamiaceae . Alain Tissier obtained his PhD in plant biochemistry from the University of Paris XI-Orsay in 1993 by working on enzymes involved in homologous recombination in plants. During his postdoc at the Sainsbury Laboratory in Norwich he worked on transposon mutagenesis and until 2003 on DNA damage responses in plants as a staff scientist of the Commissariat à l’ Energie Atomique in Cadarache, France . Since 2003, his research interests focused on plant secretory organs, especially glandular trichomes and terpenoid biosynthesis. Since 2010, he is heading the Department of Cell and Metabolic Biology at the Leibniz-Institute of Plant Biochemistry in Halle, Germany and is Professor in the Institute of Pharmacy at the Martin-Luther University, Halle-Wittenberg, Germany .
